entry.title: Integrating SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public APIs into SAP Business Application Studio via BTP Destination
entry.content:
Introduction

Connecting SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs is a fundamental requirement for modern cloud-native development on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). However, the integration path involves multiple layers of configuration that span API finalization, Communication Management in S/4HANA Cloud, destination configuration in BTP, and service consumption in CAP-based applications running in BAS.

This comprehensive blog post walks through the complete architecture, prerequisites, and step-by-step implementation of consuming S/4HANA Cloud Public APIs from SAP BAS using BTP Destination Service with Basic Authentication. Whether you're building full-stack applications, integrating business data, or extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud functionality, this guide provides the knowledge and practical patterns you need.



Chapter-1 [Current Blog]

Introduction
Part 1: Understanding API Finalization and Released APIs
Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Communication Management Setup
Part 3: SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Destination

Chapter-2
Part 4: Building CAP Services in SAP Business Application Studio
Part 5: Deployment and Runtime Configuration
Part 6: Security, Authentication, and Authorization

Chapter-3
Part 7: Troubleshooting and Common Errors
Part 8: Advanced Patterns and Best Practices

Part 1: Understanding API Finalization and Released APIs

The Clean Core Philosophy and Released APIs

Before consuming any API from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, it is critical to understand the Released API concept and the Clean Core approach that underlies all public cloud deployment strategies.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is "clean per definition," meaning that all extensions, integrations, and custom developments must adhere to released, stable APIs. These released APIs form the foundation of upgrade-stable integrations and support the long-term innovation roadmap without technical debt accumulation.

Released APIs are formally sanctioned interfaces published by SAP with explicit stability contracts. They guarantee backward compatibility across quarterly releases and are the only interfaces available for consumption in Tier 1 (cloud-ready) extension scenarios. Unlike classic SAP objects such as function modules, BAPIs, or internal tables, released APIs are versioned, documented, and managed under a formal lifecycle.

 

Types of Released APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition exposes two primary API types:

  1. OData APIs (Recommended): Open Data Protocol (OData) is the standardized protocol for creating and consuming REST-based data APIs. OData v4 (latest) and OData v2 (legacy, supported) are available. OData APIs enable simple HTTP-based data manipulation (Create, Read, Update, Delete) and are ideal for integration scenarios. They comply with REST architecture principles and support query operations like filtering, sorting, pagination, and batch operations.
  2. SOAP APIs: SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) APIs provide XML-based web services for complex synchronous operations and legacy system integrations. While less common in modern cloud scenarios, they remain supported for specific business processes.

API Finalization: The Path to Released Status

Not every API is immediately released. SAP follows a structured finalization and release process to ensure APIs meet quality, stability, and documentation standards before general availability.

API Finalization Process:

  1. Development Phase: The API is created within SAP development systems, typically to expose a specific business service or transaction. During this phase, the API undergoes internal testing and validation against functional requirements.
  2. Quality Assurance: The API is thoroughly tested for performance, security, error handling, and backward compatibility. SAP engineers verify that the API meets the stability criteria required for production consumption.
  3. Documentation and Review: Comprehensive technical documentation is prepared, including entity definitions, available operations, authentication requirements, and sample payloads. Product teams review the API for consistency with the SAP API design guidelines.
  4. Release Status Assignment: Once approved, the API receives a formal release status:
    • Released: Fully stable, documented, and available for production use. Backward compatibility is guaranteed.
    • Deprecated: The API still functions but is being phased out. A successor API is typically identified.
    • Beta: The API is available for testing but may change before final release.
    • Internal: The API is used only within SAP systems and is not available for external consumption.
  5. Publication on SAP Business Accelerator Hub: Released APIs are published on SAP Business Accelerator Hub (https://api.sap.com/), the central repository for discovering and testing all public SAP APIs. The hub provides metadata, EDMX (Entity Data Model XML) files, sandbox environments, and usage examples.

Discovering Released APIs

To find and evaluate released APIs for your integration scenario:

  1. Navigate to SAP Business Accelerator Hub at https://api.sap.com/
  2. Filter by Product: Select "SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition"
  3. Filter by API Type: Choose between OData and SOAP
  4. Search by Business Area: Use keywords related to your business process (e.g., "Business Partner," "Sales Order," "Purchase Requisition")
  5. Review API Details: For each API, examine:
    • Entity structure and available fields
    • Supported operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete)
    • Authentication requirements
    • Service URL and path
    • Communication Scenario (the binding mechanism in S/4HANA Cloud)
    • Scope items and business authorization objects
    • Deprecation status and recommended successors

API Examples: Common Released APIs for S/4HANA Cloud Public

  • API_BUSINESS_PARTNER (OData v2): Exposes master data for business partners (customers and suppliers)
  • API_SALES_ORDER_SRV (OData v2): Provides sales order creation, modification, and retrieval
  • API_PURCHASE_REQUISITION (OData v2): Enables purchase requisition management
  • A_BusinessPartner (OData v4): The modern successor to API_BUSINESS_PARTNER, offering improved performance

 

Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Communication Management Setup

Communication Management Architecture

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Communication Management is the inbound and outbound integration gateway that exposes APIs securely with centralized credential and authorization management. Before any external system (including BAS applications on BTP) can consume an S/4HANA Cloud API, a Communication Arrangement must be created in the source S/4HANA Cloud tenant.

The Communication Management architecture comprises four components:

  1. Communication Scenario: A predefined or custom integration pattern that specifies which inbound and outbound services are exposed. SAP provides hundreds of prebuilt scenarios (e.g., SAP_COM_0008 for Business Partner creation and read).
  2. Communication System: A representation of the external system (in this case, the SAP BTP subaccount) that will call the API. It acts as a trusted endpoint and stores authentication metadata.
  3. Communication User: A technical user created specifically for API access. The communication user holds credentials (username and password) and authorization roles for executing specific API operations. Unlike business users, communication users are designed for machine-to-machine (M2M) integration.
  4. Communication Arrangement: The runtime binding between a Communication Scenario, Communication System, and Communication Users. It activates the API, assigns authentication rules, and enables audit logging.

 Step 1: Create a Communication User in S/4HANA Cloud

A Communication User is a special technical user created exclusively for API access and integration scenarios. It operates independently of business users and is not licensed as a named user.

To create a Communication User:

  1. Log in to your SAP S/4HANA Cloud tenant with administrative credentials
  2. Open Launchpad and search for "Maintain Communication Users" app
  3. Click "New" to create a new communication user
  4. Fill in Required Fields:
    • User Name: A unique identifier, e.g., INT_BTP_USER
    • Description: E.g., "Communication User for BTP Integration"
    • Password: A strong, randomly generated password
    • Confirm Password: Retype for verification
    • Allowed System Access Range: Typically leave empty for standard scenarios
  5. Save the communication user

Step 2: Create a Communication System

A Communication System is a logical representation of the calling system (SAP BTP in this scenario). It establishes trust between S/4HANA Cloud and the external system and specifies the authentication method.

To create a Communication System:

  1. Open Launchpad and search for "Communication Systems" app
  2. Click "New" to create a new system
  3. Fill in Details:
    • System ID: A unique identifier, e.g., BTP_SUBACCOUNT_01
    • System Name: A descriptive name, e.g., "SAP BTP Integration"
    • System Type: Leave as default or specify HTTP-based integration
  4. In the "General" section:
    • Inbound Only: Set to ON (since BTP will call S/4HANA Cloud inbound APIs)
    • Technical Data: Note the System ID for later reference
  5. In "Inbound Communication" section:
    • Inbound User: Select the communication user created in Step 1
    • Authentication: Choose Basic Authentication for direct credential-based access
  6. Save the communication system

 

Step 3: Create a Communication Arrangement

A Communication Arrangement activates the integration by binding a Communication Scenario, Communication System, and Communication User together. It's the final step that "switches on" API access.

To create a Communication Arrangement:

  1. Open Launchpad and search for "Communication Arrangements" app
  2. Click "New" to create a new arrangement
  3. Select Communication Scenario: Browse and select the scenario matching your API. For example:
    • SAP_COM_0008: Business Partner – Read & Create
    • SAP_COM_0148: Sales Order – Read
    • For custom scenarios, search for your business process name
  4. Configure Communication System:
    • Select the communication system created in Step 2
    • Inbound User: Should auto-populate with the communication user assigned to the system
  5. Review Scope and Authorization:
    • The Communication Arrangement displays which inbound and outbound services are available
    • Some scenarios include data replication services (outbound) which you can disable if not needed
    • Verify that the required business processes are included
  6. Save and Activate the arrangement

Verifying the Communication Arrangement:

After saving, the arrangement is active. To verify successful creation:

  • The arrangement status changes to Active
  • The Service URL is displayed (e.g., https://my-s4-tenant-api.s4hana.ondemand.com/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER)
  • The Authentication method (Basic) is confirmed
  • The Inbound User shows the communication user assigned

Capturing Connection Details:

Note the following for use in BTP Destination configuration:

  • Service Root URL: https://<your-tenant-id>-api.s4hana.ondemand.com (e.g., https://my12345-api.s4hana.cloud.sap)
  • API Path: /sap/opu/odata/sap/<API_NAME> (e.g., /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER)
  • Communication User: The username created in Step 1
  • Communication User Password: The password set in Step 1
  • Client: Typically 100 (default client in S/4HANA Cloud)

 

Part 3: SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Destination Configuration

BTP Architecture: Destinations as Connectivity Bridges

SAP BTP Destination Service is the centralized credential and endpoint registry that sits between your CAP application running in BAS and remote systems like S/4HANA Cloud. Destinations abstract the complexity of authentication, URL management, and security policies, enabling developers to reference a destination by name without managing credentials directly in code.

Key Architecture Principles:

  1. Credential Management: Credentials are stored encrypted within the Destination Service, not in application code or configuration files
  2. Audit Trails: All destination access is logged, providing compliance and security visibility
  3. Dynamic Configuration: Destinations can be updated centrally without redeploying applications
  4. Proxy Layer: The Destination Service acts as a proxy, handling authentication header injection, token generation, and request forwarding
  5. Scope: Destinations are defined at the BTP Subaccount Level, ensuring centralized governance

Creating a Destination for S/4HANA Cloud with Basic Authentication

Prerequisites:

  • Access to BTP Cockpit with Connectivity → Destinations permissions
  • Communication User credentials from S/4HANA Cloud
  • Service URL and API path from the Communication Arrangement

 Step-by-Step Configuration:

  1. Open BTP Cockpit and navigate to your Subaccount
  2. In the left navigation, under Connectivity, click Destinations
  3. Click "New Destination" (or "Create → From Scratch")
  4. Configure Main Properties:

Field

Value

Name

S4_BusinessPartner (or any descriptive name)

Type

HTTP

Description

Destination to S/4HANA Cloud Business Partner API

URL

https://<your-tenant-id>-api.s4hana.ondemand.com/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER

Proxy Type

Internet

Authentication

BasicAuthentication

User

Communication user (e.g., INT_BTP_USER)

Password

Communication user password

 

Table 1: BTP Destination Configuration - Main Properties

  1. Add Additional Properties (click Add Property multiple times):

Key

Value

Purpose

sap-client

100

Specifies the SAP client (default for S/4HANA Cloud)

WebIDEEnabled

true

Makes destination visible in BAS OData tools

WebIDEUsage

odata_gen,odata_abap

Enables OData metadata generation

HTML5.DynamicDestination

true

Allows runtime destination resolution

HTML5.Timeout

60000

Timeout in milliseconds (60 seconds)

 

Table 2: BTP Destination Configuration - Additional Properties

  1. Configure Client Trust Store (Security Tab):
    • Ensure "Use default client trust store" is checked
    • This allows the destination to verify S/4HANA Cloud's SSL certificate
  2. Save the destination

Verification:

After saving:

  1. The destination appears in the Destinations list with a green checkmark (✓)
  2. Click the destination name to view its configuration
  3. Click "Test Connection" to verify connectivity:
    • A successful test returns HTTP 200 with OData metadata
    • If the test fails, verify credentials, URL, and network connectivity

entry.title: Getting started with SAP BTP
entry.content:
This end-to-end tutorial helps you set up your SAP BTP Trial and build a full-stack application using:

  • SAP CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model)

  • SAP HANA Cloud
  • SAP Business Application Studio (BAS)
  • SAP Fiori Elements
  • Cloud Foundry Deployment
  • Approuter + XSUAA Authentication

This guide is ideal for students, beginners, and consultants who want to understand how real full-stack applications are built on SAP BTP.

Creating a SAP BTP Trial Account

Access SAP BTP Cockpit

Go to: https://account.hana.ondemand.com/

Click Create Account → This creates:

  • A Global Account

  • A Default Subaccount
  • Access to BTP Cockpit services like BAS, HANA Cloud, etc.

     

Understanding Global Account, Directories & Subaccounts

Global Account:

This is the root-level account that contains all subaccounts, users, quotas, and entitlements.

Directories

Directories help organize subaccounts logically such as:

  • Development

  • Testing
  • Production

How to create:
Account Explorer → Create → Directory

Subaccount

A Subaccount is where the actual development happens. We can:

  • Enable services

  • Deploy applications
  • Create destinations
  • Manage entitlements
  • Select region + environment

Steps:
Account Explorer → Create → Subaccount

Entitlements:

Entitlements are your service quotas — they define which services your subaccount can use (e.g., HANA Cloud, XSUAA, Destinations).

You can always allocate or modify entitlements for each subaccount.

Boosters — Automated Guided Configuration

Boosters help you set up complex scenarios with just a few clicks, such as:

  • SAP HANA Cloud

  • SAP Build Apps
  • SAP Build Process Automation
  • CAP + Fiori Full-stack setup

Navigate to:
Boosters → Start

Cloud Foundry: Spaces & Instances

Space

A space is a workspace inside Cloud Foundry used for:

  • Deploying apps

  • Managing services

 Instance

An instance is a running version of a service like:

  • Destination

  • XSUAA
  • HANA Cloud
  • HTML5 Apps Repository

 

Setting Up SAP HANA Cloud

Go to:
Subaccount → Services → Instances & Subscriptions
Select SAP HANA Cloud

If you face a permission error → assign the user:

In the left-hand panel, go to Security > Users

 SAP HANA Cloud Administrator role collection
Subaccount Admin

Mapping HANA Instance to Cloud Foundry

Mapping allows CAP HDI containers to deploy artifacts to HANA Cloud.

Instance → Actions → Manage Configuration
Click Sign in to Cloud Foundry → Add Mapping → Review → Save

Setting Up SAP Business Application Studio (BAS)

Create a Dev Space

Open BAS → Create Dev Space:

Full-Stack Cloud Application

Enable:

  • Workflow module
  • SAP HANA Tools
  • SAP HANA Performance Tools

Open the Dev Space once it turns RUNNING.

Building a CAP Project

Project Steps:

  • Open the workspace

  • Update mta.yaml file → Change database path ‘gen/db’ to ‘db’
  • Update package.json →Replace existing CDS code -
"cds": {
    "build": {
      "tasks": [
        {
          "for": "hana",
          "dest": "../db"
        },
        {
          "for": "node-cf"
        }
      ]
    },
    "requires": {
      "db": {
        "kind": "hana-cloud"
      }
    }
  • Install dependencies:
npm install
  • To get Additional files in db folder
npm install -g hana-cli
hana-cli createModule

Add CDS files - Right click on db folder - 

  • /db/e_learning.cds
namespace app.e_learning;
using { Language, managed } from '@sap/cds/common';

type string50 : String(50);

entity Categories {
    key id          : UUID;
    name            : string50;
    description     : String(100);
    Courses         : Association to many Courses on Courses.category=$self;
}

entity Courses : managed {
    key course_id   : UUID;
    course_name     : string50;
    price           : String(100);
    Language        : Language;
    category        : Association to Categories;
}
  • /srv/eLearning_srv.cds 
using app.e_learning from '../db/e_learning';

service eLearning {
  entity Categories as projection on e_learning.Categories;
  entity Courses as projection on e_learning.Courses;
}

Build Project

cds build

Deploying to SAP HANA Cloud

  • Go to DB module → Deploy

  • Open HDI container → load data

  • Import using SAP HANA Database Explorer

Now, right click on table and click on Open Data

Running the App Locally

cds bind -2 e_Learning-db:SharedDevKey
npm install
cds watch --profile hybrid

Deployment to Cloud Foundry

mbt build

Deploy

cf deploy mta_archives/e_Learning_1.0.0.mtar

Adding Approuter + XSUAA for Authentication

Approuter

Provides a single entry point for your application and handles routing & authentication.

Create using BAS:
Right-click → Create MTA Module from Template → Approuter

XSUAA

Authentication is different from authorization

Authentication - Ensures the user is valid and can access the system.

Authorization - Checks the scopes/roles

Adds OAuth2.0-based authentication & authorization.

cds add xsuaa
npm install

This generates:

  • xs-security.json
  • Required scopes/roles

Generating a Fiori Application:

Using templates:
Right-click → Create MTA Module from Template → SAP Fiori App

Run: 

cds watch

Great article, Punith! I've been working with SAP CI for a few years now, and I have to admit - I've never actually come across a standard prepackaged iFlow that could be used with only configuration out of the box. entry.title: Re: A-Z Performance Testing for integrations... And why?
entry.content:
Hi @MateuszPiotrowski, 

Thanks for your comment. Unfortunately we see very often Performance Testing for integration flows (especially Async are being neglected. But this eventually comes with a price, and usually heavy one. 

Testing Async is fairly easy as well. even if we do not have all automation set and all logs accessible to the testing tool. Receiver systems for Async API usually have its own logs - so getting this info (manually) and consolidation with JMeter data (again manually, if needed) is not such a difficult task. 

At the end we will see, that in Async API flows (or Event API flows) the weakest link is usually the Receiver itself (not middleware). Learning this in time - even if we have to do some test results consolidation manually - its just worth it...

entry.title: Re: A-Z Performance Testing for integrations... And why?
entry.content:
@stevang Absolutely agree - in my experience, backend/receiver is almost always the bottleneck, not middleware. middleware components (Event Mesh, CPI) are designed to handle high throughput, but the receiver application's processing logic, database locks, or custom code is where things slow down.

Manual consolidation of logs for async measurement works well when you're dealing with a handful of interfaces, but when you're managing dozens ?  doing this manually for each one becomes impractical. At that scale, having some level of automation becomes essential.

I'm curious - have you seen any organization successfully scale this approach, perhaps by building custom scripts or leveraging observability platforms to automate the log correlation /analysis ?

entry.title: Simplifying UI5 Library Use on BTP by Bundling Libraries at Build Time
entry.content:
Background: Reusing UI5 Libraries on SAP BTP

When using a custom UI5 library on SAP BTP, the most common approach is to deploy the library source first and then consume it from other applications.

Based on previous blogs and samples, there are two established approaches, which can be broadly categorized into an older and a newer approach.

Approaches Without CDM (older approach)

  • Shared Destination Instance: In this approach, the library and the consuming applications share the same destination service instance (blog 1).
  • Separate Destination Instances per Application: Each application uses its own destination service instance, and the consuming application explicitly defines destinations for the library (HTML5 app repo host and UAA) (blog 2).

Approaches with CDM (newer approach)

  • Library as Content Provider: When using CDM, the library defines a content provider destination and a cdm.json file containing skeleton definitions for catalogs, groups, and roles. The consuming application depends on the library's HTML5 app repo host (blog 3).

Benefits and Limitations of Deploying Libraries Independently

Deploying the library source as an independent artifact has a clear advantage: when the library changes, it needs to be fixed or updated in only one place.

However, this approach makes the deployment of consuming applications more complex. The application's mta.yaml requires additional, library-specific configuration. This complexity is manageable when only a single shared library is used, but it increases significantly when multiple independent libraries are involved.

Using CDM can reduce this complexity. However, CDM is primarily intended for defining the layout and content structure in SAP Build Work Zone from the application side, and in my opinion, it is more suitable for SaaS-oriented solutions. Therefore, it does not fit well with workflows where application developers implement the apps, while a separate authorization or platform team designs and manages the Work Zone contents.

An Alternative Approach: Bundling the Library at Build Time

In this blog, a different approach is introduced: bundling the library source directly into the consuming application at build time and deploying them together. The main advantages of this approach are simpler application configuration and the removal of dependencies on resources defined by the library, such as destinations or HTML5 app host service instances.

The main drawback is that when the library changes, each consuming application must be redeployed individually. On the other hand, this also has a positive side effect: incompatible changes in the library can be introduced without impacting existing applications that rely on older versions.

Developing and Deploying Applications with a Bundled UI5 Library

The following sections describe how to develop an application by bundling a UI5 library directly into the consuming application.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Fiori tools is installed in Visual Studio Code.

Steps Overview

  1. Create the UI5 library
  2. Create an application that consumes the library
  3. Configure the project for deployment
  4. Build and Deploy

 

1. Create the UI5 library

Open the Command Pallete and select "Fiori: Open Reusable Library Generator".

Fill the project details as shown below.

Clean Up the Generated Library

Under the /src/<namespace>/<libraryname> folder, remove all sample content except for the following files:

  • .library
  • library.ts
  • messagebundle.properties

After the cleanup, the folder structure should look like the image below.

Replace the Example Controller Logic

The generated library.ts file contains example controller logic that is not required for this scenario. Replace its content with the implementation provided in the following GitHub repository:

https://github.com/miyasuta/fiori-use-library-blog/blob/main/com.myorg.reuselib/src/com/myorg/reuselib/library.ts

This sample library provides a dialog with controller logic attached.

The complete implementation can be found here:

https://github.com/miyasuta/fiori-use-library-blog/tree/main/com.myorg.reuselib/src/com/myorg/reuselib

Since the project uses TypeScript, make sure to build the library after applying the changes:

npm run build

 

2. Create an Application That Consumes the Library

Next, create a UI5 application that consumes the library.

Generate the application

Open the Application Generator and select the "Basic" template (other templates such as List Report can also be used).

Enter the project details. Select both "Add Deployment Configuration" and "Add SAP Fiori Launchpad Configuration".

For the deployment configuration:

  • Select Cloud Foundry as the target
  • Select "Add Application to Managed Application Router", since the app will run on SAP Build Work Zone

Configure the SAP Fiori Launchpad settings as shown below.

Add a Reference to the Library

Now that both the library and the consuming application exist, connect them.

Open the Command Pallete and select "Fiori: Add Reference to SAP Fiori Reusable Libraries".

Select the project folder path (consumerapp) and the library.

This action adds entries to manifest.json, ui5.yaml, and ui5-local.yaml.

manifest.json

  "sap.ui5": {
    "flexEnabled": true,
    "dependencies": {
      "minUI5Version": "1.143.2",
      "libs": {
        "sap.m": {},
        "sap.ui.core": {},
        "com.myorg.reuselib": {
          "lazy": false
        }
      }
    },

ui5.yaml / ui5-local.yaml

By default, the src path does not point to dist. Because the library is implemented in TypeScript, it is adjusted to reference the compiled output in the dist folder.

    - name: fiori-tools-servestatic
      beforeMiddleware: fiori-tools-proxy
      configuration:
        paths:
          - path: /resources/com/myorg/reuselib
            # src: ../com.myorg.reuselib/src/com/myorg/reuselib
            src: ../com.myorg.reuselib/dist/resources/com/myorg/reuselib
            fallthrough: false

To ensure that TypeScript recognizes the library's type definitions, add the following to tsconfig.json:

  "include": [
    "./webapp/**/*",
    "../com.myorg.reuselib/dist/resources/**/*.d.ts"
  ]

 

Use the Library in the Application

Now the library can be used in the application locally.

In this example, a button is placed on the UI. When pressed, it opens a dialog defined in the library. After the user presses OK, a callback is triggered, allowing the consuming application to execute its own logic.

View

<mvc:View controllerName="miyasuta.consumerapp.controller.View1"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns="sap.m">
    <Page id="page" title="{i18n>title}">
        <Button id="pressMeButton" text="Press Me" press="onOpenDialog" />
    </Page>
</mvc:View>

Controller

import Controller from "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller";
import MyDialogHanlder, { MyDialogHandler$SubmitEvent } from "com/myorg/reuselib/controller/MyDialogHandler";
import MessageToast from "sap/m/MessageToast";

/**
 *  miyasuta.consumerapp.controller
 */
export default class View1 extends Controller {

    /*eslint-disable @typescript-eslint/no-empty-function*/
    public onInit(): void {

    }

    public onOpenDialog(): void {
        const dialogHandler = new MyDialogHanlder();
        dialogHandler.attachSubmit((event: MyDialogHandler$SubmitEvent) => {
            const message = event.getParameter("message");
            MessageToast.show(`Dialog submitted with message: ${message}`);
        });
        dialogHandler.open();

    }
}

 

3. Configure the Project for Deployment

This section describes the key configuration required to bundle the library source into the consuming application at build time.

 

3.1 Library Project Configuration

ui5.yaml

Update metadata.name to include the full namespace:

metadata:
  # name: "reuselib"
  name: com.myorg.reuselib

Add a resources section to the builder configuration to exclude test resources from the build:

builder:
  resources:
    excludes:
      - "/test-resources/**"

The complete builder section will look like this:

 

3.2 Application Project Configuration

package.json

Add the library as a dependency, using a relative path within the workspace:

  "dependencies": {
    "com.myorg.reuselib": "file:../com.myorg.reuselib"
  },

ui5-deploy.yaml

Configure the builder to include the library dependency during the build:

builder:
  settings:
    includeDependency:
      - com.myorg.reuselib

Add includeDependencies to the ui5-task-zipper configuration so that the library resources are included in the final ZIP archive:

    - name: ui5-task-zipper
      afterTask: generateCachebusterInfo
      configuration:
        ...
        includeDependencies:
          - com.myorg.reuselib
        ...

The complete builder section will look like this:

xs-app.json

Add the following route to ensure that library resources are served from the application instead of the UI5 CDN.

    {
      "source": "^/resources/com/myorg/reuselib/(.*)$",
      "target": "/resources/com/myorg/reuselib/$1",
      "service": "html5-apps-repo-rt",
      "authenticationType": "xsuaa"
    },

manifest.json

Add resourceRoots so that the library can be resolved when launched from SAP Build Work Zone:

  "sap.ui5": {
    "flexEnabled": true,
    "resourceRoots": {
      "miyasuta.mylibrary": "./resources/com/myorg/reuselib"
    }

index.html

Add the library to data-sap-ui-resource-roots so that it can be resolved when running from the HTML5 Application Repository:

        data-sap-ui-resource-roots='{
            "miyasuta.consumerapp": "./",
            "com.myorg.reuselib": "./resources/com/myorg/reuselib"
        }'

 

4. Build and Deploy

Run the following command in the consuming application project:

npm run build:mta

Verify that the library resources are included under the dist/resources folder.

Deploy the application to Cloud Foundry:

npm run deploy

Finally, verify that the application can be launched successfully from both the HTML5 Application Repository and SAP Build Work Zone.

Conclusion

Reusing UI5 libraries on SAP BTP offers multiple established patterns, but these often introduce additional deployment complexity for consuming applications.

This blog presented an alternative approach: bundling the UI5 library source into the consuming application at build time. While this approach requires changes across several configuration files, all adjustments remain application-scoped, reducing cross-project dependencies and overall complexity.

This approach is not intended to replace existing patterns, but to provide a pragmatic option for scenarios where applications are developed and deployed independently.

entry.title: Securing SAP Business AI: A Multi-Layer Architecture for Enterprise Trust
entry.content:
(Jana Subramanian serves as the Head of Cybersecurity and Compliance in SEA and is recognized as a Fellow of Information Privacy (FIP) by the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP). He supports strategic customer engagements on cybersecurity, data privacy, multi-cloud security architecture, contractual assurance, and compliance.)

Introduction

Enterprise AI has moved decisively from experimentation to strategic necessity. Organizations today are no longer debating whether to adopt AI, but how to deploy it securely, responsibly, and at scale without breaking existing business processes, security models, or compliance obligations.

SAP Business AI represents SAP’s enterprise-first approach to this challenge. Rather than treating AI as a standalone capability, SAP embeds intelligence directly into business applications and executes AI-driven actions within the same architectural boundaries that govern core enterprise workloads. This means AI operates with full awareness of business context, user identity, authorization, data sensitivity, and regulatory constraints.

This blog provides an end-to-end architectural walkthrough of SAP Business AI using a layered reference architecture. It explains how Joule serves as the unified AI interaction layer, how agentic execution patterns enable AI to plan and act within controlled boundaries, how identity and principal propagation enforce enterprise authorization, and how security, privacy, and governance are built into every stage of the AI lifecycle.

Multi-Layered Architecture

The SAP Business AI architecture is designed as a layered system, where each layer has a distinct responsibility while remaining tightly integrated with adjacent layers. This separation of concerns allows enterprises to adopt AI capabilities incrementally, without compromising identity, security, or governance controls.

Layer 1: Experience Layer

The experience layer represents the entry point for business users and developers interacting with AI capabilities. It includes familiar SAP user touchpoints such as SAP Fiori, SAP Build Work Zone, Joule Co-Pilot, and SAP Mobile Start. This layer is responsible for presenting AI capabilities in a way that feels native to SAP applications rather than as a separate AI tool.

Joule sits prominently in this layer as the conversational interface, translating user intent into structured requests that can be processed by the AI runtime. SAP Build also appears in this layer, reflecting how custom applications and extensions can expose AI-driven experiences using the same architectural foundation. Importantly, this layer does not execute AI logic itself. It captures intent and context and hands off responsibility to the orchestration layer below.

 

Component

Purpose

SAP Fiori

Enterprise web applications that surface AI-assisted insights and actions

SAP Build Work Zone

Unified digital workplace that exposes AI-driven tasks and recommendations

Joule Co-Pilot

Conversational AI interface that captures user intent across SAP applications

SAP Mobile Start

Mobile-first access to AI-assisted workflows and insights

SAP Build

Low-code and no-code tools to design AI-enabled user experiences

Layer 2: Orchestration Layer - Coordinating AI Execution

The orchestration layer is where SAP Business AI moves beyond simple prompt-and-response interactions. This layer coordinates how AI requests are prepared, governed, and executed. It includes AI Core as the execution backbone, SAP Generative AI Hub (via SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad) as the controlled access point to foundation models, and supporting capabilities such as prompt templating, data masking, content filtering, and agent memory.

This layer is responsible for shaping requests before they ever reach a model. Prompts are templated to enforce consistency, sensitive data is masked where required, and content filters are applied to ensure responsible usage. Agent memory allows the system to maintain conversational and task context across multiple steps, enabling more advanced, agentic execution patterns. By centralizing orchestration here, SAP ensures that AI behavior is predictable, repeatable, and policy aware.

 

Component

Purpose

AI Core

Runtime for executing AI workloads and agentic execution loops under policy control

Generative AI Hub

Centralized, harmonized access to foundation models with enterprise governance

Prompt Templating

Standardizes prompt structure to ensure consistency, control, and predictable model behavior

Data Masking

Detects and masks sensitive data before it is sent to models

Content Filter (Input)

Evaluates and filters user input to enforce responsible AI usage

Content Filter (Output)

Screens model responses to prevent unsafe or non-compliant output

Agent Memory

Session Context Management (Agent Memory Pattern) – Maintains conversational and task context across multi-step interactions

Harmonized API Access

Provides a consistent interface for invoking models and AI capabilities across providers

Layer 3: Grounding Layer - Anchoring AI in Enterprise Context

The grounding layer ensures that AI responses are based on enterprise reality rather than generic model knowledge. This layer is responsible for context and evidence retrieval and connects AI execution to authoritative business data and documents.

As shown in the architecture, grounding sources include SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere, document repositories, knowledge graphs, and the SAP HANA Vector Engine. SAP Integration Suite also plays a role in accessing distributed enterprise systems. Together, these components allow AI to retrieve relevant business context using semantic and vector-based techniques, ensuring that responses are accurate, explainable, and aligned with enterprise data models.

This layer is fundamental to trust. By grounding AI outputs in traceable enterprise sources, SAP Business AI enables explainability and reduces the risk of hallucinations or contextually incorrect actions.

 

Grounding Source

Use Case

Context and Evidence Retrieval

Real-time retrieval of relevant business context and supporting evidence

SAP Knowledge Graph

Semantic relationships between business entities and concepts

SAP Business Data Cloud

Unified business data foundation across SAP applications

SAP Datasphere

Analytical and data warehousing context for AI grounding

Document Grounding

Retrieval of unstructured business documents such as contracts and PDFs

SAP HANA Cloud Vector Engine

Vector-based semantic search and similarity matching

SAP Integration Suite

Real-time access to distributed and third-party systems

Layer 4:  Execution Layer - Turning Insight into Action

The execution layer is where AI-driven decisions are translated into concrete business actions. This includes SAP APIs, Joule Skills, function calling, Model Context Protocol servers, agent-to-agent interactions, and SAP Build Process Automation workflows.

This layer enables AI to move from recommendation to execution, whether that means calling an SAP API, triggering a workflow, or coordinating actions across systems. Importantly, execution is not autonomous in an uncontrolled sense. Tool access and actions are constrained by identity, authorization, and runtime policies inherited from the underlying platform. This ensures that AI can act, but only within the same boundaries that apply to human users and technical integrations.

 

Execution Mechanism

Purpose

SAP APIs

Invoke business operations in SAP applications such as S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, and other SAP services

Joule Skills

Encapsulate reusable business actions that can be triggered through Joule

Function Calling

Enable structured invocation of predefined actions based on AI decisions

Model Context Protocol (MCP) Servers

Open standard providing standardized context and tool interfaces for AI-driven execution (governed via AI Agent Hub in SAP LeanIX)

Agent-to-Agent (A2A) Interaction

Industry protocol enabling coordinated actions across multiple specialized agents

SAP Build Process Automation (BPA)

Trigger workflows and business processes requiring orchestration or approvals

Layer 5: Governance Layer - Sustaining Trust Across the AI Lifecycle

The governance layer spans the entire architecture and ensures that SAP Business AI remains compliant, auditable, and manageable over time. It includes capabilities such as AI Agent Hub in SAP LeanIX, Joule Studio, AI Launchpad, model registries, data privacy integration, and audit log services.

This layer governs both design-time and runtime aspects of AI. Before deployment, use cases, risks, and models are reviewed and approved. During runtime, actions are logged, monitored, and subject to human-in-the-loop controls where required. After deployment, lifecycle management, regulatory alignment, auditability, and traceability ensure that AI systems continue to meet enterprise and regulatory expectations.

 

Governance Component

Purpose

AI Agent Hub in SAP LeanIX

Central visibility and governance of AI agents and their relationships

Joule Studio

Design-time configuration and management of Joule skills and AI interactions

AI Launchpad

Model lifecycle management, versioning, and approval workflows

Model Registry

Central inventory of approved AI models and configurations

Data Privacy Integration

Enforcement of data protection and privacy controls across AI usage

Audit Log Service

Centralized logging of AI actions for auditability and compliance

Human-in-the-Loop Controls

Approval gates for sensitive or high-risk AI-driven actions

Cross-Cutting Controls: Security, Privacy, and Observability

Running alongside all layers are cross-cutting enterprise controls covering identity and access, data protection, content safety, and observability. Authentication, principal propagation, OAuth-based access, encryption, tenant isolation, audit logging, and monitoring are not tied to a single layer but are enforced consistently across the entire stack.

This design reinforces a core principle of SAP Business AI: SAP Business AI is designed to extend existing enterprise security controls rather than introduce parallel security models. Identity, authorization, and audit principles that govern SAP applications are applied consistently to AI-driven interactions.

Agentic AI Execution Flow: From User Intent to Governed Business Action

This diagram illustrates broadly how SAP Business AI executes agentic workflows in a controlled, enterprise-grade manner. The flow begins with the user interacting through Joule in the experience layer. Joule captures intent and context but does not execute logic itself. Instead, it forwards the request to the agent orchestration layer running on SAP BTP, where the execution lifecycle is coordinated under policy control.

At the core of this flow is SAP AI Core, which manages the agent runtime and enforces execution boundaries. Large language model calls are routed through SAP GenAI Hub, while short-term memory maintains session context and intermediate reasoning. Grounding retrieves enterprise-relevant context and evidence from long-term memory sources such as SAP Datasphere, SAP S/4HANA data, documents, and the SAP HANA Vector Engine. Based on this grounded context, the agent proposes the next action. Crucially, all actions pass through control execution code that enforces authorization, audit logging, and human confirmation where required. Only then are SAP APIs, workflows, or automations invoked. Results are returned through the orchestration layer back to Joule, accompanied by explanations and supporting evidence.

This execution model ensures that SAP Business AI can reason and act, but never outside established enterprise controls. AI-driven actions follow the same identity, authorization, and audit principles as human-initiated actions, making the system predictable, explainable, and trustworthy at scale.

 

Flow Element

Responsibility

User

Initiates the request or question through an SAP application

Joule (Experience Layer)

Captures user intent and presents AI-driven responses

Agent Orchestration

Coordinates the agent workflow and execution sequence

AI Core

Executes the agent runtime with policy enforcement

LLM Call (via GenAI Hub)

Performs language reasoning using governed model access

Short-Term Memory

Maintains session context and intermediate results

Grounding

Retrieves enterprise context and Top-K evidence for accuracy

Long-Term Memory

Provides access to business data, documents, and vectors

Agent Proposes Tool Call

Determines the next business action to execute

Control Execution Code

Enforces authorization, audit logging, and approvals

Tool Invocation & Action

Executes SAP APIs, workflows, or automations

Results Returned to Joule

Delivers explained outcomes with supporting evidence

Key Considerations for Adoption 

While SAP Business AI provides a comprehensive architectural foundation, successful adoption requires deliberate planning:

Start with Identity, Not AI: Before enabling Joule or deploying agents, ensure your SAP BTP identity and access management foundation is solid. Principal propagation, role-based authorization, and audit logging must already be in place AI capabilities inherit these controls rather than introducing new ones.

Grounding Quality Determines AI Quality: AI outputs are only as trustworthy as the data they are grounded in. Prioritize data quality, semantic consistency, and governance in SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP Datasphere before scaling AI use cases across the enterprise.

Govern Agents Early, Not Later: The proliferation of AI agents SAP-delivered, custom-built, and third-party can quickly become unmanageable. Establish visibility and governance through the AI Agent Hub in SAP LeanIX from day one. Retrofitting governance after deployment is significantly harder.

Plan for Human-in-the-Loop by Design: Not every AI-driven action should be autonomous. Identify high-risk processes, such as financial approvals or compliance-sensitive workflows, and design explicit human checkpoints using SAP Build Process Automation before deploying agentic capabilities.

Real World Complexity

The layered architecture presented in this blog is a conceptual framework synthesized from SAP product capabilities and architectural patterns. It is intended to help readers understand how the components fit together, not to represent an official SAP reference architecture.

In practice, enterprise landscapes are rarely this clean. Organizations typically face:

Hybrid environments where on-premises SAP S/4HANA, RISE with SAP Cloud ERP Private, and GROW with SAP S/4HANA cloud, public edition, SaaS cloud deployments, requiring careful consideration of where AI processing occurs and how data flows across trust boundaries.

Bring Your Own Model (BYOM) scenarios where organizations deploy custom or third-party models in SAP AI Core, introducing additional customer responsibility for model security, bias testing, and lifecycle management.

Multi-cloud and non-SAP integrations where AI agents must access data from AWS, Azure, Google Cloud, or third-party SaaS applications each introducing distinct authentication models, data residency constraints, and compliance requirements.

Regulatory variability where AI governance requirements differ significantly across jurisdictions (for example, the EU AI Act and sector-specific regulations), requiring flexible policy enforcement rather than one-size-fits-all controls. This framework provides a starting point, but each enterprise must map it to its specific landscape, risk tolerance, and regulatory context. For a deeper look at trust boundaries and secure data flows, see Securing SAP Business AI Architectures.

Conclusion

SAP Business AI shows that enterprise-scale AI does not require compromising on security, privacy, or governance. By structuring AI as a layered architecture across experience, orchestration, grounding, execution, and governance, SAP embeds intelligence directly into business processes while ensuring that every AI interaction operates within established identity, authorization, and audit controls. Joule captures user intent, orchestration governs how AI requests are shaped and executed, grounding anchors decisions in enterprise data, and execution translates insight into action only within approved boundaries, while governance ensures lifecycle oversight and regulatory alignment. The result is an AI operating model that allows systems to reason and act with confidence, transparency, and control, moving AI from experimentation into a trusted, operational capability for the enterprise

entry.title: Simple MCP server setup for comparing Successfactors configurations across Instances
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • UseCase
  • Pre-requisites
  • MCP server development in VS code
  • Install MCP server in Claude
  • Demo Screenshots
  • Conclusion

 

 

Introduction

Model Context Protocol ( MCP)  has made quite a significant  impact on how data from the different solutions are accessed by the AI assistants or agents.  The layer to expose data from solutions have been decoupled completely from the AI assistants.

To summarise MCP -- Its a standard protocol which is understood by all AI Agents. Once  the data is registered or exposed in a MCP server , any of the AI assistants can effectively  access the data and proceed with the next steps as requested by the users.

AI assistants with MCP servers setup for a hybrid SAP Successfactors (SAP SF)suite would be able to handle a lot of usecases which requires a significant development in the traditional world.

Setup Overview

SAP SF  and on prem SAP HCM odata services can be registered as an MCP server which  can be deployed in SAP BTP platform , The MCP servers then be installed in  one of the AI assistants used by the organisations.  With this setup , it is possible to handle the below use cases  wherein once data is available , the AI assistants do the heavy lifting of processing data with LLMs

  • Compare configurations between different SAP SF instances 
  • Compare data between SAP SF and on prem 
  • Update data across SAP SF and on prem
  • Automatic updation of workbooks
  • Analyse data from SAP SF  and create dashboards
  • Create reports combing data from both SAP SF and SAP HCM payroll systems
  • And Many more

UseCase

For the blog, i would like to take a very simple use case of comparing configurations across SAP SF instances ( dev and quality or quality and production)  and develop a quick POC by leveraging the usage of MCP servers and AI assistants.

With SAP SF Configuration Transport Center,  we need to include all the modified objects manually into the Bundle and  there are possibilities of missing out moving  certain configurations  to productive instance which would result in the processes to fail.

By comparing configurations across instances --we ensure that all configs are in sync and the risk of process failing due to misconfigurations are minimized.

 

Spoiler
As this is a POC  --I  have taken so called cinematic liberty of hardcoding the credentials directly in the codebase which would/should never been done in productive environment.  Destination services of platform where the MCP server is deployed  should be used  for authentication for prod environments
Spoiler
For the POC --  the MCP server is a local server VS code and i used Claude Desktop version as an AI assistant which is free for the requirements of the POC

Pre-requisites

  • Install Claude Desktop  -- free version is enough for the POC 
  • VS code for development
  • MCP SDK  -->https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk
    • I  have used python SDK and installed the relevant python packages like "uv" as mentioned in the link above
  • Finally -- API access to atleast 2 SAP SF tenants which can be compared

MCP server development in VS code

Open the folder in VScode and run the below command in the terminal to enable the selected folder as a uv managed folder

uv init .

Add MCP dependancies with the below command in the terminal

uv add "mcp[cli]"

Once the dependancies are added , the project structure in VS code looks as below

Following is the code snippet to be included in main.py folder.

The logic is very straight forward and simple wherein we first initialize the MCP server.

We include the MCP tool via the annotation and define the function  with the name of instance and  name of the entity as an argument. The name of instance and entity name would be passed from the AI assistant to the MCP server during runtime.

The standard SAP SF metadata api url is defined in the function and using the 'requests' package, a GET call is implemented.

As the response would be xml, the python package 'xmltodict' is used to convert the xml data to json response which is then returned back.

# main.py

from typing import Any
from mcp.server.fastmcp import FastMCP
import requests
import xmltodict

#Init Server
mcp = FastMCP("SFgetConfig", dependencies=["requests","xmltodict"])

@mcp.tool()
def get_configuration(instance: str , entity: str ) -> dict[str, Any]:
    """Get Configuration metadata details for the entity within the instance"""
    username= f"<username>@{instance}"    
    password = "<password>"
    apiUrl = f"https://api12preview.sapsf.eu/odata/v2/{entity}/$metadata"
    credentials = (username, password)
    
    meta_response = requests.get(apiUrl, auth=credentials)

    meta_json = xmltodict.parse(meta_response.text.encode("UTF-8"))

    return meta_json



    
if __name__ == "__main__":
    mcp.run()

Install MCP server in Claude

Run the below command in terminal to install the MCP server with Claud configuration file.

uv run mcp install main.py

To validate, open Claude  and select File -->Settings

Navigate to the section 'Developer' and select 'Edit Config'

The claude configuration file should display the MCP server that we installed from VScode and also previously installed servers

The MCP servers are also visible in the connector sections in the  prompt window .

Now Claude is all set to interact with SAP Successfactors instance via the MCP server installed within its configuration
